articles.title: Extreme Heat Forces School Closures in South Sudan, Highlighting Climate Crisis Impact
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: South Sudan has closed all its schools for two weeks due to extreme heat wave. The education crisis is part of broader systemic challenges facing South Sudan, including a fragile health system, a postponed election due to financial constraints, and a disrupted oil-based economy following pipeline issues in Sudan.

articles.title: Melting glaciers led to almost 2 cm of sea level rise this century, says study. Why does this matter?
articles.author: Alind Chauhan
articles.summary: Melting ice from glaciers worldwide has led to the sea level rising by almost 2 cm this century alone. Glaciers have been losing 273 billion tonnes of ice each year for the last 25 years. Global sea levels have risen by more than 10 cm between 1993 and 2024, according to NASA. Coastal cities in India have witnessed a rise of 4.44 cm between 1987 and 2021.

articles.title: Researcher shows "dramatic" change in Norway glacier ice levels
articles.summary: Mountain glaciers are melting twice as fast as in the early 2000s. They lost more than 600 billion tons of ice in 2023 when David Schecter visited Svalbard, Norway, according to a new study in the Nature journal this week.

articles.title: Scientists probe gulls' 'weird and wonderful' appetites
articles.author: Helen Briggs
articles.summary: Dr Alice Risely launched a citizen science project to study gulls' diet. She wants people to upload their photos of gulls eating weird things to the project's website, Gulls Eating Stuff. UK seabirds face threats from warming oceans, overfishing and avian flu. Several gull species are on the UK red list of conservation concern.

articles.title: Scientists probe gulls' 'weird and wonderful' eating habits
articles.author: Helen Briggs
articles.summary: Gull populations in the UK are in decline due to climate change, overfishing and avian flu. Several species are on the UK red list of conservation concern. Some gulls are coming to live closer to people, adding human leftovers to their natural menu of fish, crabs, starfish and earthworms.

articles.title: South Australia to face extreme fire danger and heatwave
articles.summary: Temperatures in South Australia reached 22 degrees early Saturday morning, which is five degrees higher than expected for this time of year. Parts of southeastern Australia will remain at an extreme fire danger rating because of the high temperatures, as the heatwave sweeps the state.

articles.title: Melting glaciers pose a serious global issue
articles.author: Gulf-Times
articles.summary: The rapid melting of glaciers is a serious global issue with far-reaching consequences. Many regions depend on glaciers as a natural water reservoir. The findings are crucial for advancing our scientific understanding of global glacier changes and provide a valuable baseline to help regions address the challenges of managing scarce freshwater resources.

articles.title: Going Green: How to make your business more sustainable
articles.author: RTE
articles.summary: Climate change is transforming the business landscape right across the world. Sustainability is no longer optional for companies. Business risks associated with not taking action are increasing rapidly and far outweigh the cost of change, according to the World Economic Forum (WEF). It's time to adopt new practices and ways of working.

articles.title: Australia says China has not explained naval live-fire warning
articles.author: Marietta Daily Journal
articles.summary: Beijing broadcast a live-fire warning that forced commercial flights to change course. Australia has not received a satisfactory explanation from Beijing yet. China's warships off its east coast broadcast the warning on Saturday. Australia's government is concerned about the warning.

articles.title: Australia's Penny Wong challenges Chinese foreign minister over 'unprecedented' live fire drills off Australian coast
articles.author: Stephen Dziedzic
articles.summary: Penny Wong wants China to be more transparent about the actions of its warships off Australia's east coast. China has issued a live fire drill warning at short broadcast on a civil aircraft channel, which has angered Australia's foreign minister Penny Wong and Stephen Dziedzic.

articles.title: China conducts second live-fire drill near New Zealand
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Report from New Zealand navy personnel comes a day after similar drill forced multiple airlines to change flight paths between Australia and New Zealand. Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast to stay up-to-date on the latest news.

articles.title: This is how most life on Earth will end
articles.author: BGR
articles.summary: For now, life thrives on oxygen-rich planet, but Earth's atmosphere won't always be so welcoming. Scientists predict Earth will eventually undergo a drastic atmospheric shift, which will drive most life, including humans, to extinction, marking the end of life on Earth as we know it.

articles.title: Glaciers Are Shrinking at an Incredible Rate
articles.author: Futurism
articles.summary: Glaciers are melting at alarming rates due to human-driven climate change. In one year 273 billion tonnes of ice is lost, which is equivalent to the entire global population consuming in 30 years, assuming three liters of water per person and day per day.

articles.title: ‘Developed nations not disbursing promised climate change funding'
articles.author: The News International
articles.summary: Dr Syed Mahmood Nasir is former Executive Director of Global Climate-Change Impact Studies Centre (GCISC). He says developed nations have fallen short on their financial commitments as the actual disbursement of the promised $100 billion in climate aid. He believes developed nations bear a greater historical responsibility for emissions.

articles.title: Why Is Chocolate So Expensive Right Now?
articles.author: Wired
articles.summary: Rising temperatures, erratic rainfall, and other climate impacts are throttling cocoa production and driving up chocolate prices due to rising temperatures and erratic rainfall. The cocoa prices are also driven up due to the rise in cocoa prices.     .

articles.title: 20 years of satellite data reveal 'staggering' levels of glaciers melting, sea levels rising
articles.author: Space
articles.summary: Glaciers worldwide have lost 273 billion tonnes of ice in the past two decades. Global warming is driving sea levels to rise at an accelerated pace, according to a decades-long comprehensive analysis.   Â. Â   y

articles.title: New research raises alarms over extreme heat scorching Australia's cities
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Temperatures above 35 degrees Celsius in Sydney in 2019 and 2020 were under-reported, according to new research. This has implications for cities across Australia, including Melbourne and Adelaide, where temperatures are expected to reach 35 degrees in the next few years.

articles.title: Increase in heatwave-related death in Australia
articles.author: Famagusta Gazette
articles.summary: There is an increase in heatwave-related deaths due to human-induced climate change. People in cities are at a much higher risk of mortality due to the heatwave, according to two separate studies published on Tuesday by the University of Queensland (UQ).

articles.title: Chinese Live Firing in Tasman Sea is not the same as West sailing through disputed South China Sea
articles.author: Martyn Bradbury
articles.summary: Some flights over the Tasman Sea have been forced to change their routes because of Chinese naval exercises off the Australian east coast. New Zealand supports ships sailing through the South China Sea and considers China's live-firing in Tasman Sea a provocation directly to their interests.
